properties.name: Peace Corps Botswana - Molepolole I
properties.description:
**The purpose of this task is to trace missing buildings and roads.**

The Peace Corps' NGO capacity building program, in close partnership with the District AIDS Coordinator's office, in Botswana is requesting assistance to inventory buildings for the tracking of service provision for orphans and vulnerable children and people living with HIV in Molepolole village. While the map will be organized and housed at the District AIDS Coordinator's office at the district government headquarters, it will be shared with NGOs providing services in Molepolole. Much help is needed to map buildings in the village as it is said to be the largest (by landmass) in the world.

properties.short_description: The Peace Corps' NGO capacity building program, in close partnership with the District AIDS Coordinator's office, in Botswana is requesting assistance to inventory buildings for the tracking of service provision for orphans and vulnerable children and people living with HIV in Molepolole village. properties.instructions:
**Please trace all buildings and roads.**

Map roads and smaller paths for as far as you can follow them. *Use Bing Imagery.*

Save with credit to HOTOSM. Comment the changeset with: *#hotosm-project-1022 #PeaceCorps #PCBotswana source=Bing*

**Buildings:**
Please label all buildings as general buildings. The Peace Corps Volunteer and the community will add their detailed local knowledge to the map after we complete the task.

Square the corners of all buildings by pressing “S” on your keyboard after labeling the building. You may see huts in Botswana; make your buildings perfectly round by pressing “O”.

**Roads:**
“The road conditions in Africa do not always correspond to their economic and social role. A road typology should be based on the road importance and not on the surface or the visual appearance of the road”. -- [Highway Tag Africa, OpenStreetMap Wiki](http://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Highway_Tag_Africa)

It can be hard to know the economic and social role of a road, but we can guess that a road is important to trace if it connects other roads, clusters of buildings, or towns and villages. Please use the tags below, taken from the OpenStreetMap Wiki:

Tertiary Road: The roads interconnecting villages and the major streets in towns of some importance.

Residential Road: The roads in residential areas except for major streets that interconnect with various roads (i.e. primary, secondary, tertiary).

Unclassified Road: The roads serving for interconnection of smaller villages and hamlets.

Track: The small roads going outside the residential areas, mainly for agricultural and forestry purposes. In general these roads do not have a connecting function with other roads. 

*For more information, please visit: [http://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Highway_Tag_Africa](http://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Highway_Tag_Africa)*

properties.name: Peace Corps Dominican Republic - Angostura
properties.description:
**The purpose of this task is to trace missing buildings and roads.**

Peace Corps' Community Economic Development program in the Dominican Republic is requesting assistance to inventory buildings and roads in Angostura. There is currently no detailed map available in the village. The map of Angostura will initially be used to support the work of local small business owners in promoting eco-tourism initiatives, but the base map data would be useful in a variety of public health and other contexts. More detailed basemap data (roads, buildings, streets) is needed to assist the program.

properties.name: Peace Corps Botswana - Mosetse
properties.description:
The Peace Corps Public Health program in Botswana has requested assistance building a base map in Mosetse. A Peace Corps Volunteer is working closely with village leadership, including the local health clinic, to prepare and implement strategies for adding local knowledge to and using the map. 

After the completion of the base map, Mosetse health clinic staff will create additional map layers to track tuberculosis and other home based care patients. The clinic will also create a map of households benefiting from the malnutrition program. Currently, the clinic has struggled to find a mechanism for recording the location of these patients, resulting in staff creating individual mental maps of their patients' homes that can be lost when there is turnover. Patients may not receive consistent medications and other services as a result. The local police will also use the map to mark incidences of crime. 

Finally, the Peace Corps Volunteer will continue to work closely with village leadership to identify additional use cases and will present the map and its data to the Kgosi, or village chief, at the kogtla, or traditional Botswanian village assembly.

properties.name: Peace Corps Botswana- Gobojango Area
properties.description:
Botswana’s National Malaria Elimination Program will begin its annual indoor-residual spraying (IRS) campaign in a few months in Gobojango. IRS has played an important role in propelling Botswana to reach the elimination phase in its fight against malaria. In order to be effective, IRS needs to reach over 90% coverage in malaria endemic areas. Gobojango clinic would like to use a comprehensive map of the village to plot which houses have been reached by IRS. Mapping out residential homes and being able to mark houses that have been offered IRS services will allow for more efficient and complete IRS coverage in the village. 

This map could be the pilot program for IRS mapping in the region and eventually lead to better IRS coverage in other malaria endemic regions in our Bobirwa district. Please help us in the fight against malaria!

The program conducts annual bed-net distribution campaigns in the town for malaria prevention. Volunteers will use the base map as part of monitoring and evaluation activities, particularly to conduct geo-spatial analysis of malaria related behavior change over time and space.

properties.name: Peace Corps Botswana - Francistown
properties.description: The Peace Corps Public Health program in Botswana is requesting assistance to inventory buildings and roads for HIV/AIDS prevention and treatment programs. Francistown is the second largest city in Botswana and suffers one of the highest rates of HIV in Botswana due to the fact that it is a stopover for many travelers, both domestic and foreign. It can be difficult to reach the entirety of Francistown's population -- over 100,000 -- with HIV/AIDS treatment and prevention programs. With the help of OpenStreetMap, the District AIDS Office along with the District Health Management Team, plans to map the entirety of Francistown. Upon completion of the map these organizations will be able to better analyze areas with high rates of HIV/AIDS. The Health Management team also plans to use OSM and geospatial data to improve operations of its tuberculosis and sexually transmitted infection clinics.

properties.name: Peace Corps Mozambique - Milange
properties.description:
**The purpose of this task is to trace missing buildings and roads.**

**Justification**

The Peace Corps Public Health program and the President's Malaria Initiative in Mozambique are requesting assistance to inventory buildings and roads for malaria prevention programs. The data will be used to analyze the effectiveness of bednet distribution campaigns and Indoor Residual Spraying campaigns. The base map will also be used in efforts to determine how long households have used bednets before upcoming distributions and to identify the rate at which people use bednets compared to malaria rates in the household. properties.name: Peace Corps Botswana - Mathathane
properties.description:
**The purpose of this task is to trace missing buildings and roads.**

**Justification**

The implementation of the National Strategic Plan for Malaria Elimination in Botswana is progressing well and has reached the goal of reducing morbidity and mortality rates through implementing intensified malaria interventions. One measure being taken towards this effort is the annual indoor-residual spraying (IRS) campaign, which plays an important role towards malaria elimination in Botswana. For IRS to be effective, there needs to be over 90% coverage in malaria endemic areas. The IRS team will be heading to Mathathane in October and in conjunction with the Mathathane Clinic, Peace Corps Botswana's health program will help work to reach the coverage needed through IRS and community mapping. Mapping out residual homes and being able to mark houses that have been offered IRS services will allow for more efficient and complete IRS coverage in the village. Mapping Mathathane will aid in providing better records of IRS coverage and moving Botswana one step closer towards malaria elimination.

To learn to map, please watch the tutorial videos at www.mapgive.state.gov.

properties.name: Peace Corps Zambia -- Mukonchi
properties.description:
**The purpose of this task is to trace missing buildings and roads.**

**Justification**

The Peace Corps public health program in Zambia is requesting assistance in creating a base map for the town of Mukonchi. The local health clinic will use the map data to better visualize the limits of their catchment area and for improved navigation to home-based care and emergency care patients.

**Please trace all buildings and roads.**

Map roads and smaller paths for as far as you can follow them. *Use Bing Imagery.*

**Buildings:**
Please label all buildings as general buildings. The Peace Corps Volunteer and the community will add their detailed local knowledge to the map after we complete the task.

Square the corners of all buildings by pressing “S” on your keyboard after labeling the building. You may see huts; make your buildings perfectly round by pressing “O”.

**Roads:**
“The road conditions in Africa do not always correspond to their economic and social role. A road typology should be based on the road importance and not on the surface or the visual appearance of the road”. --Highway Tag Africa, OpenStreetMap Wiki

It can be hard to know the economic and social role of a road, but we can guess that a road is important to trace if it connects other roads, clusters of buildings, or towns and villages. Please use the tags below, taken from the OpenStreetMap Wiki:

Tertiary Road: The roads interconnecting villages and the major streets in towns of some importance.

Residential Road: The roads in residential areas except for major streets that interconnect with various roads (i.e. primary, secondary, tertiary).

Unclassified Road: The roads serving for interconnection of smaller villages and hamlets.

Track: The small roads going outside the residential areas, mainly for agricultural and forestry purposes. In general these roads do not have a connecting function with other roads. 

**For more information, please visit: http://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Highway_Tag_Africa.**

properties.name: Peace Corps Zambia- Kagunda Area
properties.description:
**The purpose of this task is to trace missing buildings and roads.**

**Justification**

The Kagunda community health committee in collaboration with Peace Corps Zambia, is requesting assistance to inventory buildings and roads for malaria prevention programs. 

Kagunda is a community of over 6,000 people and is known to have the highest rate of Malaria in Chipata District,  Eastern Province,  Zambia.

As a community health committee, it is our intention to track and monitor the rates of Malaria per individual village but also the tracking and monitoring of prevention.  From bed net checks to IRS (Indoor Residual Spraying), we hope to keep a visual record and by doing so promote accountability and adherence for the safety and well being of our community.

properties.name: Peace Corps Senegal - Sanela
properties.description:
**The purpose of this task is to trace missing buildings and roads.**

**Justification**
The Peace Corps Stomp Out Malaria program in Senegal is requesting assistance building a better base map of insert village name. In collaboration with the Senegalese Ministry of Health and the Kedougou region health system, Peace Corps and Senegalese public health professionals will conduct a study to determine the importance of geographic proximity in malaria transmission. In other words, the team seeks to determine whether all members of a household should be preemptively treated for malaria if one member tests positive. The map data will be used to perform geographic analysis of data collected during the study. 

Through the MapGive project, the Humanitarian Information Unit (HIU) of the U.S. Department of State is providing the OpenStreetMap community access to updated satellite imagery services to help assist with humanitarian mapping.

The George Washington University’s Geography Department is supporting this project through remote mapping.

properties.name: Peace Corps Madagascar - Kianjavato
properties.description:
**The purpose of this task is to trace missing buildings and roads.**

**Justification**
The Bed Net Surveillance Program is a Peace Corps Madagascar initiative. The goal of the program is to reduce malaria morbidity and mortality in participating communities by encouraging community members to regularly use mosquito nets. The Bed Net Surveillance Program will monitor LLIN (Long Lasting Insecticide-treated Nets) usage through the help of GIS (Geographic Information System) based technologies. Community leaders will focus sensitization efforts on households that do not routinely sleep under mosquito nets in order to achieve high bednet coverage rates.

properties.changeset_comment: #hotosm-project-1294 #PeaceCorps #PCSenegal #GWU #MapGive Source=WordView-2 & WorldView-3, DigitalGlobe, NextView, 1 Dec 2014, 1 Jan 2015, & 4 Jan 2015
properties.name: Peace Corps Senegal - Saraya
properties.description:
**The purpose of this task is to trace missing buildings and roads.**

**Justification**
The Peace Corps Stomp Out Malaria program in Senegal is requesting assistance building a better base map of Saraya. In collaboration with the Senegalese Ministry of Health and the Kedougou region health system, Peace Corps and Senegalese public health professionals will conduct a study to determine the importance of geographic proximity in malaria transmission. In other words, the team seeks to determine whether all members of a household should be preemptively treated for malaria if one member tests positive. The map data will be used to perform geographic analysis of data collected during the study. 

Through the MapGive project, the Humanitarian Information Unit (HIU) of the U.S. Department of State is providing the OpenStreetMap community access to updated satellite imagery services to help assist with humanitarian mapping.

The George Washington University’s Geography Department is supporting this project through remote mapping.
properties.author: CourtneyMClark
properties.short_description: The Peace Corps Stomp Out Malaria program in Senegal is requesting assistance building a better base map of Saraya. In collaboration with the Senegalese Ministry of Health, Peace Corps and Senegalese public health professionals will conduct a study to determine the importance of geographic proximity in malaria transmission. In other words, the team seeks to determine whether all members of a household should be preemptively treated for malaria if one member tests positive. The purpose of this task is to trace missing buildings and roads.

**Please trace all buildings and roads.**

Map roads and smaller paths for as far as you can follow them. 

**Buildings:**

Square the corners of all buildings by pressing “S” on your keyboard after labeling the building. You may see round huts; make your buildings perfectly round by pressing “O”.

**Roads:**

It can be hard to know the economic and social role of a road, but we can guess that a road is important to trace if it connects other roads, clusters of buildings, or towns and villages. Please use the tags below, taken from the OpenStreetMap Wiki:

Unclassified Road: The roads serving for interconnection of smaller villages and hamlets.

Track: The small roads going outside the residential areas, mainly for agricultural and forestry purposes. In general these roads do not have a connecting function with other roads. 

*For more information, please visit: http://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Highway_Tag_Africa.*

Imagery Details
This imagery is from Digital Globe’s WorldView-2 and WorldView-3 satellite, and is made up of images taken on December 1st 2014, January 1st 2015, and January 4th 2015. The images are orthorectified for terrain corrected geographic precision. Additionally, the images have been contrast stretched using a custom stretch and processed into a Tiled Map Service (TMS) for performance.

**The purpose of this task is to trace missing buildings and roads.**

**Justification**

Analavory is a small town of about 2,000 people in the district of Manakara, SE Madagascar. It's composed of four separate villages: Analavory, Satramaha, Antavibe, and Ambodivoangy. The primary economic activity is rice farming.

properties.name: Peace Corps Ethiopia - Dilla
properties.description:
**The purpose of this task is to trace missing buildings and roads.**

**Justification**

Dilla is the capital of the Gedeo Zone, located about 350 kilometers south of Addis Ababa. The area is home to over 100,000 people and is a lush, green hub for the coffee industry. The Dilla Town Health Office is working to address issues of water scarcity and water-borne disease and has collaborated with the Peace Corps Ethiopia Community Health program to promote water and sanitation hygiene to the community. Improved map data will help these efforts.

properties.name: Peace Corps Kyrgyzstan - Barskoon
properties.description:
**The purpose of this task is to trace missing buildings and roads.**

**Justification**

Barskoon is a town of around 7,000 people in northeast Kyrgyzstan. It sits on the south shore of Lake Issyk-Kul and at the base of the Tien Shan Mountain Range. Community members are starting to develop the eco-tourism sector in this beautiful area and have expressed interest in accessing accurate, updated geographic information for their activities.

properties.name: Peace Corps Madagascar - Ranomafana
properties.description:
**The purpose of this task is to trace missing buildings and roads.**

**Justification**
The Bed Net Surveillance Program is a Peace Corps Madagascar initiative. The goal of the program is to reduce malaria morbidity and mortality in participating communities by encouraging community members to regularly use mosquito nets. The Bed Net Surveillance Program will monitor LLIN (Long Lasting Insecticide-treated Nets) usage through the help of GIS (Geographic Information System) based technologies. Community leaders will focus sensitization efforts on households that do not routinely sleep under mosquito nets in order to achieve high bednet coverage rates.
properties.author: CourtneyMClark
properties.short_description: The Bed Net Surveillance Program is a Peace Corps Madagascar initiative. The goal of the program is to reduce malaria morbidity and mortality in participating communities by encouraging community members to regularly use mosquito nets. properties.instructions:
**Please trace all buildings and roads.**

Map roads and smaller paths for as far as you can follow them. 

**Buildings:**
Please label all buildings as general buildings. The Peace Corps Volunteers and the community will add their detailed local knowledge to the map after we complete the task.

Square the corners of all buildings by pressing “S” on your keyboard after labeling the building. You may see round huts; make your buildings perfectly round by pressing “O”.

**Roads:**
“The road conditions in Africa do not always correspond to their economic and social role. A road typology should be based on the road importance and not on the surface or the visual appearance of the road”. --Highway Tag Africa, OpenStreetMap Wiki

It can be hard to know the economic and social role of a road, but we can guess that a road is important to trace if it connects other roads, clusters of buildings, or towns and villages. Please use the tags below, taken from the OpenStreetMap Wiki:

Tertiary Road: The roads interconnecting villages and the major streets in towns of some importance.

Residential Road: The roads in residential areas except for major streets that interconnect with various roads (i.e. primary, secondary, tertiary).

Unclassified Road: The roads serving for interconnection of smaller villages and hamlets.

Track: The small roads going outside the residential areas, mainly for agricultural and forestry purposes. In general these roads do not have a connecting function with other roads. 

*For more information, please visit: http://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Highway_Tag_Africa.*

properties.name: Peace Corps Botswana - Goodhope
properties.description:
**The purpose of this task is to trace missing buildings and roads.**

**Justification**

The Peace Corps Public Health program in Botswana is requesting assistance creating a better base map of Goodhope. The Peace Corps program and Botswanan social workers will use the base map to track service provision for orphans and vulnerable children. 

Through the MapGive project, the Humanitarian Information Unit (HIU) of the U.S. Department of State is providing the OpenStreetMap community access to updated satellite imagery services to help assist with humanitarian mapping.

properties.name: Peace Corps Mozambique -- Guro
properties.description:
The Peace Corps Mozambique Education and Public Health programs are requesting assistance building an improved base map of Guro. The data will be used by a variety of stakeholders, including local education professionals engaging students in mapmaking and public health professionals working to prevent and treat malaria. 

Through the MapGive project, the Humanitarian Information Unit (HIU) of the U.S. Department of State is providing the OpenStreetMap community access to updated satellite imagery services to help assist with humanitarian mapping.

properties.name: Peace Corps Botswana - Bobonong
properties.description:
**The purpose of this task is to map roads, buildings and compound walls.**

**Justification**

The Peace Corps Botswana Public Health program, along with the District Health Management Team and the Home-Based Care NGO in Bobonong, is requesting assistance building a better base map of Bobonong. Initially, the base map data will be used to conduct mapping exercises and geographic analysis in support of malaria prevention. Objectives include mapping malaria cases to better understand transmission trends and conduct contact tracing and mapping Indoor Residual Spraying campaigns. The organizations would also like to use the OSM data to monitor TB cases, optimize routing while providing care to home-based patients, and better allocate resources to orphans and vulnerable children.  Teams will be in the field conducting Field Papers in mid-March.

properties.name: Peace Corps Botswana - Mochudi
properties.description:
**The purpose of this task is to trace missing buildings and roads.**

**Justification**

Peace Corps' Public Health program in Botswana is requesting assistance to inventory buildings and roads for HIV/AIDS and TB prevention and treatment programs. Mochudi is a large village in Botswana. Like many areas of Botswana Mochudi suffers from high rates of HIV/AIDS prevalence as well as disproportionately high rates of TB. It is difficult to reach all of Mochudi's population, which is nearly 45,000 with HIV/AIDS treatment and prevention programs. With the help of OpenStreetMap, the District AIDS Office along with the District Health Management Team, plans to map the entirety of Mochudi, and later all of Kgatleng District. Upon completion of the map these organizations will be able to better analyze areas with high rates of HIV/AIDS. The District Health Management Team also plans to use OSM and geospatial data to improve operations of its TB, HIV/AIDS and sexually transmitted infection clinics.

properties.name: Peace Corps Mozambique -- Maracuene
properties.description:
Peace Corps Volunteers in Mozambique are working to promote map literacy, improve local health center catchment, and educating on the importance of maps in understanding existing and needed resources for community development. In Marracuene District specifically, Peace Corps is supporting local counterparts in conducting epidemiological tracking of malarial cases to advocate need for stronger preventative measures, which an up-to-date base map plays an integral role. Malaria prevention and control remains a major U.S. foreign assistance objective and PMI's Strategy fully aligns with the U.S. Government's vision of ending preventable child and maternal deaths and ending extreme poverty. Under the PMI Strategy, the U.S. Government's goal is to work with PMI-supported countries and partners to further reduce malaria deaths and substantially decrease malaria morbidity, towards the long-term goal of elimination. More information can be found at www.pmi.gov.

Data created from this mapping effort will help Indoor Residual Spraying programs in Mozambique plan for the upcoming spray campaign as well as a program coordinated through the Local Peace Corps Volunteer to map heath related resources. After the base map is completed by remote mappers, Peace Corps Volunteers in Maputo Province will work with their Mozambican counterparts to complete Field Papers in key villages and towns and add local knowledge to OSM.

This data is intended to help PMI, PC, and community actors with project scope, spray planning, and community resources management. Specifically with IRS, teams apply insecticide to the walls of houses to kill mosquitoes which transmit malaria. These updated maps will help make smart choices on exactly where to spray, and improve spray team activities by providing project managers with improved estimates of the number of households and structures.
properties.author: Choquette33
properties.short_description: The Peace Corps Public Health program in Mozambique is requesting assistance building a better base map of Maracuene. The base layer data will be used to create more advanced maps for support of local counterparts in conducting epidemiological tracking of malarial cases to advocate need for stronger preventative measures

properties.name: Peace Corps Madagascar -- Marofaria Hamlet
properties.description:
**The purpose of this task is to trace missing buildings and roads.**

**Justification**
The Bed Net Surveillance Program is a Peace Corps Madagascar initiative. The goal of the program is to reduce malaria morbidity and mortality in participating communities by encouraging community members to regularly use mosquito nets. The Bed Net Surveillance Program will monitor LLIN (Long Lasting Insecticide-treated Nets) usage through the help of GIS (Geographic Information System) based technologies. Community leaders will focus sensitization efforts on households that do not routinely sleep under mosquito nets in order to achieve high bednet coverage rates.

properties.name: Peace Corps’ Stomp Out Malaria - Kachikau
properties.description:
**The purpose of this task is to trace missing buildings and roads.**

**Justification**

Peace Corps Volunteers working with their local counterparts are assisting with the coordination of the government’s Indoor Residual Spraying (IRS) program. It has been found that if 90% of buildings are treated, Malaria can be virtually eliminated from a community. To track their efforts towards this tipping point, a baseline map of the community and all of its structures is needed.

properties.name: Peace Corps Nicaragua - Nueva Guinea
properties.description:
**The purpose of this task is to trace and label missing buildings and roads.**

**Justification**

Peace Corps volunteers working with their local Counterparts are training community members in mapping and using OSM.  This will provide their communities, who are currently under-served both in terms of available baseline maps and in terms of local capacity to contribute to digital maps, with an opportunity to build their capacity to create and use OSM maps. 

Through the MapGive project, the Humanitarian Information Unit (HIU) of the U.S. Department of State is providing the OpenStreetMap community access to updated satellite imagery services to help assist with humanitarian mapping.
properties.author: Choquette33
properties.short_description: The Peace Corps program in Nicaragua is requesting assistance to inventory buildings and roads for a baseline map. This task will enable Peace Corps Nicaragua volunteers to train community members at their host sites in use of OSM.
properties.instructions:
**Please trace all buildings.**

Map roads and smaller paths for as far as you can follow them. 

Save with credit to HOTOSM. Comment the changeset with *#hotosm-project-871 #PeaceCorps #PeaceCorpsNicaragua #MapGive Source=WorldView-2, DigitalGlobe, NextView, 10 Jan 2013*

Imagery Details
 
This imagery is from Digital Globe’s WorldView-2 satellite taken acquired on January  10, 2013. The image is orthorectified for terrain corrected geographic precision. Additionally, the images have been contrast stretched using a custom stretch and processed into a Tiled Map Service (TMS) for performance.

properties.name: Peace Corps Botswana - Ghanzi I
properties.description:
**The purpose of this task is to trace missing buildings and roads.**

The Peace Corps' Health Program in Botswana is requesting assistance to inventory buildings and roads for analysis and tracking of condom dispensaries and HIV/AIDS hot spots in the area. Ghanzi is located in the Kalahari and is home to the resettled San people. The San are considered one of the most disenfranchised populations in the country. Botswana has the second highest estimated prevalence of HIV/AIDS in the world.

properties.name: Peace Corps Botswana - Shakawe I
properties.description:
**The purpose of this task is to trace missing buildings and roads.**

**Context**

Botswana's National Malaria Program and the Peace Corps' Health Program in Botswana are requesting assistance to inventory buildings and roads for geographical reconnaissance related to malaria prevention. Map data will be used in Indoor Residual Spraying campaigns and for follow-up of individual malaria cases. Nestled against the Okavango Delta, Shakawe and surrounding villages had some of, if not the the highest number of confirmed malaria cases in Botswana during the 2013-2014 transmission season.

properties.short_description: The Peace Corps' Health program in Botswana is requesting assistance to inventory buildings and roads for tracking cases of tuberculosis and to analyze accessibility of health facilities and ARV treatment centers to the local population. More detailed basemap data (roads, buildings, streets) is needed to assist the program.
properties.instructions:
**Please trace all buildings and roads.**

Map roads and smaller paths for as far as you can follow them. *Use Bing Imagery.*

Save with credit to HOTOSM. Comment the changeset with: *#hotosm-task-899  #PeaceCorps #PeaceCorpsBotswana source=Bing*

**Buildings:**
Please label all buildings as general buildings. The Peace Corps Volunteer and the community will add their detailed local knowledge to the map after we complete the task.

Square the corners of all buildings by pressing “S” on your keyboard after labeling the building. You may see huts in Botswana; make your buildings perfectly round by pressing “O”.

**Roads:**
“The road conditions in Africa do not always correspond to their economic and social role. A road typology should be based on the road importance and not on the surface or the visual appearance of the road”. --Highway Tag Africa, OpenStreetMap Wiki

It can be hard to know the economic and social role of a road, but we can guess that a road is important to trace if it connects other roads, clusters of buildings, or towns and villages. Please use the tags below, taken from the OpenStreetMap Wiki:

Tertiary Road: The roads interconnecting villages and the major streets in towns of some importance.

Residential Road: The roads in residential areas except for major streets that interconnect with various roads (i.e. primary, secondary, tertiary).

Unclassified Road: The roads serving for interconnection of smaller villages and hamlets.

Track: The small roads going outside the residential areas, mainly for agricultural and forestry purposes. In general these roads do not have a connecting function with other roads. 

*For more information, please visit: http://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Highway_Tag_Africa.*

properties.name: Peace Corps Mozambique - Quelimane I
properties.description:
**The purpose of this task is to trace missing buildings and roads.**

**Context**

The Peace Corps' Health program and the President's Malaria Initiative  in Mozambique are requesting assistance to inventory buildings and roads to evaluate the reach and impact of mosquito net distributions and Indoor Residual Spraying Campaigns. The programs also need assistance in order to collect accurate GPS coordinates of all of the health centers in Zambezia province. Zambezia province, home to Quelimane, has the highest rate of malaria incidence in Mozambique at 54%. 

Through the MapGive project, the Humanitarian Information Unit (HIU) of the U.S. Department of State is providing the OpenStreetMap community access to updated satellite imagery services to help assist with humanitarian mapping.

This imagery is from Digital Globe’s GeoEye-1 satellite taken acquired on February 11, 2015. The image is orthorectified for terrain corrected geographic precision. properties.name: Peace Corps Namibia - Omega
properties.description:
**The purpose of this task is to trace missing buildings and roads.**

**Context**

The Peace Corps’ Stomp Out Malaria program in Namibia is requesting assistance to inventory buildings for implementation of community level Indoor Residual Spraying and future Bednet Distribution programs.  It has been found that if 80% of buildings are treated through an Indoor Residual Spraying campaign, malaria can be virtually eliminated from a community. To track their efforts towards this tipping point, a baseline map of the community and all of its structures is needed.

properties.name: Peace Corps Botswana - Thamaga I
properties.description:
**The purpose of this task is to trace missing buildings and roads.**

The Peace Corps' Health Program in Botswana is requesting assistance to inventory buildings and roads for analysis and tracking of condom dispensaries in the area. The map will also be used to identify additional locations for new dispensaries and to conduct regular refills of current dispensaries. Botswana has the second highest estimated prevalence of HIV/AIDS in the world. More detailed basemap data (roads, buildings, streets) is needed to assist the program.

The map will also be used to identify additional locations for new dispensaries and to conduct regular refills of current dispensaries. Botswana has the second highest estimated prevalence of HIV/AIDS in the world. More detailed basemap data (roads, buildings, streets) is needed to assist the program.

properties.name: Peace Corps Guyana - Georgetown
properties.description:
**The purpose of this task is to trace missing buildings and roads.**

The Peace Corps program in Guyana is training its Peace Corps Volunteers in the use of OpenStreetMap and other GIS tools in their community-level development projects. Map edits will be validated by experienced OpenStreetMap contributors within Peace Corps after the training. The resulting map will be used by Peace Corps Guyana to supplement Volunteer safety and security programs and, of course, the existence of an improved map of Georgetown will be beneficial to any number of other organizations and businesses in this developing country.

properties.name: Peace Corps Botswana - Ramotswa I
properties.description:
**The purpose of this task is to trace missing buildings and roads.**

The Peace Corps' Health Program in Botswana is requesting assistance
to inventory buildings and roads in Ramotswa. There is currently no
detailed map of the village available to the District Health
Management Team or to individual clinics.  The map of Ramotswa
will primarily be used to keep track of patients in need of
monitoring, such as Home Based Care Patients, and new mothers and
babies.  The map data will also have many other uses, including
showing drivers and patients how to navigate to health facilities and
keeping track of disease outbreaks in the village.  The map will also
be used to keep track of HIV+ patients who need access to
Anti-Retroviral medication.  Botswana has the second highest estimated
prevalence of HIV/AIDS in the world. More detailed basemap data
(roads, buildings) is needed to assist the program.
